Tumblr for posting my thoughts, reflections and other stuff pertaining to various things and interests in my life.

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: So, speaking of George R. R. Martin’s original notes to his publisher, I have to say the first moment I began to suspect not...
caption:
So, speaking of George R. R. Martin’s original notes to his publisher, I have to say the first moment I began to suspect not only that the notes were not only still relevant in many ways, but that the tv series would likely get as close as it possibly could to whatever ending Martin was working towards, and that the show would move all the characters into place to get to that ending, was this recapt trailer that HBO posted before Season 7 started, back in 2017.

For me, this trailer pretty much confirmed the “five core characters” Martin mentioned in his notes as still being the core five characters for the story. Because at certain points in the trailer, each of those five characters are specifically highlighted, signaling the five of them out among all the other characters who are in the trailer, as if saying “Hey! Make sure you pay specific attention to these people!”  

Tyrion: 1:10

Daenerys: 1:45  

Jon: 2:40

Bran: 3:38

Arya: 4:03

And now, recently, we’ve just had the #ForTheThrone stills and promos a few weeks ago. And, once again, all five of these characters each specifically got one. In fact, the only other characters to get one of these promos, who are still alive, are Cersei and the Night King (as much as you can call a White Walker “alive” at any rate). And those two are clearly the two final antagonists. 

So while I think many things in those publisher notes got changed or moved or altered completely, I still think it hold a lot of still-relevant information as well. Maybe even more than anyone suspects.

blog.name: jonsameta
blog.title: you are to me
blog.description: Welcome to JonsaMeta! We are a blog that attempts to collate interesting meta, speculation, and a dash of tinfoil from across the Jonsa fandom. Tracking #jonsameta

tags: He seems to be possibly omniscient
But only with enough time to go back in the past
summary: You think that Bran will know of what’s gone on between Jon and Dany before Jon arrives to WF?
question: You think that Bran will know of what’s gone on between Jon and Dany before Jon arrives to WF?
answer:
Dear nonny,

difficult to say: I mean Bran got this ‘upload’ on virtually everything during season 6, and it seems that he can visit any point in the past and have a look at what happened. On the other hand, he doesn’t seem to do that regularly.

At the end of season 6 he saw that Jon is his cousin and Lyanna his mom, and yet until Samwell Tarly came to Winterfell he never checked if Jon perhaps was legitimate - a question that is not exactly unimportant.

So, I would say, that the show very clearly states that he could know. He could go back in time and make a face at Jon and Daenerys on the boat instead of just giving a voiceover that states how they are related…

The question is: Will he do that? I must admit, that I don’t know. Bran might think his cousin is important enough that he checks on him (and stumbles on Jon and Daenerys) but it is also quite possible that he thinks that this would not be important.

Bran like Jon is quite set on dealing with the threat of the White Walkers, and the thought that Jon’s intimate life might become important might not cross his mind. I would like to say, that he wouldn’t even want to look at his cousin’s intimate life but he’s already shown that he is not concerned about that very much. He told Sansa she looked beautiful at her wedding after all - and unless he was talking about a possible future wedding - this was a very inconsiderate thing to do. This emotional detachment is quite different from BookBran by the way and I miss BookBran very much. BookBran would not know about anything that didn’t happen in front of a heart tree, or so I understand Bran’s seeings in the books.

Thanks for the ask!

~Fedon

summary: Bran Stark and the wheel: GRR Martin’s subtle critics of the feudal system
title: Bran Stark and the wheel: GRR Martin’s subtle critics of the feudal system
body:
Please note: this is not a criticism of Bran in any way.

Re-reading Bran’s ACOK POV chapters, I came to wonder if the author wasn’t slipping some subtle criticism of the feudal “wheel” everyone seems to be talking about. Anyway, there’s two things I’d like to talk about here: the distribution of resources and characterization of the peasant class.

The distribution of resources

The serving men brought every dish to Bran first, that he might take the lord’s portion if he chose. By the time they reached the ducks, he could eat no more. After that he nodded approval at each course in turn, and waved it away. If the dish smelled especially choice, he would send it to one of the lords on the dais, a gesture of friendship and favor that Maester Luwin told him he must make. He sent some salmon down to poor sad Lady Hornwood, the boar to the boisterous Umbers, a dish of goose-in-berries to Cley Cerwyn, and a huge lobster to Joseth the master of horse, who was neither lord nor guest, but had seen to Dancer’s training and made it possible for Bran to ride. He sent sweets to Hodor and Old Nan as well, for no reason but he loved them. Ser Rodrik reminded him to send something to his foster brothers, so he sent Little Walder some boiled beets and Big Walder the buttered turnips. (Scene from the Harvest Feast, Bran ACOK)

Lords normally collect a food tax from peasants in exchange for protection and access to the castle in case of war. The food served at the feast was probably grown, harvested and paid to the Lord of Winterfell by peasants living around the castle. Everybody’s welcomed at the feast, from “smallfolk from the winter town” to Winterfell men, lords and ladies. The food isn’t distributed equally, however, and those who gets the best dishes aren’t necessarily the ones who worked for it the most (farmers and such):

-If you’re highborn, or if the Lord of Winterfell likes you, you get choices of meat and sweets

-If the Lord of Winterfell doesn’t like you, you get boiled beets and turnips

-If you’re part of the smallfolk, you get the leftovers.

Can you spot the problem? It’s the “divide and choose” in reverse: the one who cuts the cake (Bran) not only get the first pick, but also distributes the remaining pieces himself. Who gets what is entirely up to him. 

The characterization of the peasant class

Or: Hodor.

A while ago, I found an essay discussing the smallfolk’s representation in Disney’s Beauty and the Beast, how the castle workers were “thingified” into, essentially, the only thing that mattered about them. The cooks have no purpose in life beyond what they cook, so let’s turn them into pots and saltshakers. Cleaners sweep and scrub, that’s what they do, so that’s what they are. Let’s turn them into brooms and mops. They’re not persons, only mere utilities.

This applies perfectly to Hodor: his job is to be someone else’s limbs, so he has strong arms, a strong back, strong legs. A mind? He doesn’t need one. Speech? Unnecessary. Name? Nope – “Hodor” isn’t his name, merely the designation of what he does (holding a door). Hodor’s purpose in life revolves around carrying highborn on his back. He’s big. He holds everything together (Bran wouldn’t last long without him), and he virtually has no voice: he’s the perfect representation of the medieval commoner. Martin knew what he was doing when he wrote him.

-If you’re highborn, or if the Lord of Winterfell likes you, you get choices of meat and sweets

-If the Lord of Winterfell doesn’t like you, you get boiled beets and turnips

-If you’re part of the smallfolk, you get the leftovers.

Can you spot the problem? It’s the “divide and choose” in reverse: the one who cuts the cake (Bran) not only get the first pick, but also distributes the remaining pieces himself. Who gets what is entirely up to him. 

The characterization of the peasant class

Or: Hodor.

A while ago, I found an essay discussing the smallfolk’s representation in Disney’s Beauty and the Beast, how the castle workers were “thingified” into, essentially, the only thing that mattered about them. The cooks have no purpose in life beyond what they cook, so let’s turn them into pots and saltshakers. Cleaners sweep and scrub, that’s what they do, so that’s what they are. Let’s turn them into brooms and mops. They’re not persons, only mere utilities.

This applies perfectly to Hodor: his job is to be someone else’s limbs, so he has strong arms, a strong back, strong legs. A mind? He doesn’t need one. Speech? Unnecessary. Name? Nope – “Hodor” isn’t his name, merely the designation of what he does (holding a door). Hodor’s purpose in life revolves around carrying highborn on his back. He’s big. He holds everything together (Bran wouldn’t last long without him), and he virtually has no voice: he’s the perfect representation of the medieval commoner. Martin knew what he was doing when he wrote him.

blog.name: coolkarmact
blog.title: The Comedian
blog.description: In the end, we're all satisfied. And you're set free.

text:
We are not now that strength which in old days
Moved earth and heaven, that which we are, we are;
One equal temper of heroic hearts,
Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will
To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.
source:
Ulysses, by Alfred Lord Tennyson

I am re-watching Skyfall and the scene where the last few lines of Ulysses are being recited by M gives some strong Stark siblings vibes.

Also, the title track of Skyfall would make for a great trailer song for GOT season 8!

summary: I think a lot of people had a problem with Bran speaking about Sansa's wedding night. But for me, I felt Bran may very well have...
question: I think a lot of people had a problem with Bran speaking about Sansa's wedding night. But for me, I felt Bran may very well have seen what Sansa went through, and he tells her he's sorry she had to go through such horrors in their own home. His emotional senses are very dulled now and his sense of propriety has gone down too (like how he dismissed Meera the way he did), yet he still had enough to let Sansa know he understands she went through hell and empathized with her plight.
answer: I admit I was pretty bitter that he never brought up anyone else’s traumas, just Sansa’s. Like what was the point? Did Sansa express a need to hear someone tell her they empathised with her because of that? If they had written that scene it would have at least shown Bran trying to reach out through the wall of incalculable knowledge he has acquired. At least because of that scene no one can accuse Sansa of stealing his inheritance or anything and despite the show barely featuring Bran I did like the other scenes that they shared. Hopefully S8 will bring more Sansa and Bran because he’s her favourite brother.

Hopefully S8 will bring more Sansa and Bran because he’s her favourite brother.

If they had written that scene it would have at least shown Bran trying to reach out through the wall of incalculable knowledge he has acquired. summary: ASOIAF characters + TES deities ❯ Bran Stark - Hermaeus Mora ❝His sphere is the scrying of the tides of Fate, of the past and...
caption:
ASOIAF characters + TES deities
❯ Bran Stark - Hermaeus Mora

❝His sphere is the scrying of the tides of Fate, of the past and future as read in the stars and heavens. He is not known for being good or evil; he seems to be the keeper of both helpful and destructive knowledge, although he usually sees all seekers of any knowledge as his servants. His Plane of Oblivion, the Apocrypha, is an endless library where all forbidden knowledge can be found. Those who wander into Apocrypha in search of truth are often lost there forever.❞
